docs.lead_paragraph: Men who have been screened for prostate cancer by the most commonly used tests have no greater chance of surviving the disease than those who have not been screened at all, new research has found. A report on the research, published yesterday in The Archives of Internal Medicine, found that neither a prostate specific antigen test, known as a P.S.A., nor a rectal examination worked to reduce deaths from prostate cancer.

headline.main: Report Casts Fresh Doubts On Prostate Cancer Testing

docs.abstract: Dr John Concato of Veterans Affairs Connecticut Healthcare System leads study that shows men who have been screened for prostate cancer have no greater chance of surviving illness than those men who were not screened; research, which is published in Archives of Internal Medicine, suggests that doctors present all options to patients considering screening (M)
docs.snippet: Neither of the most commonly used tests to screen for prostate cancer worked to reduce deaths from the disease, a new study suggests.

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Smith has difficulty talking for very long. He also has trouble sleeping and eating, and he has lost more than 50 pounds in the last three years. He has even considered taking his life. The source of his misery? It sounds like a biblical curse in a Mel Brooks movie.

headline.main: A Horrific Case of Hiccups, a Novel Treatment

docs.abstract: In extreme cases of chronic hiccups doctors are exploring use of vagus nerve stimulator surgically implanted under skin near collarbone; device is approved by Food and Drug Administration to treat seizures and to help with severe depression, but was found to have some connection to hiccup stimulation; Dr Bryan R Payne, Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center neurosurgeon, performed first procedure, described in Journal of Neurosurgery, in 2004; device described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: For chronic hiccups sufferers, the key to peace may lie in the vagus nerve.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is no secret that some women who take birth control pills lose interest in sex. They have been reporting this side effect to their doctors since oral contraceptives came into wide use 40 years ago. ''Little by little, my boyfriend and I started noticing that I was just never in the mood. Never,'' said Cody, a 27-year-old San Francisco woman, who asked that her last name not be used for reasons of privacy.

headline.main: When the Pill Arouses That Urge for Abstinence

docs.abstract: Boston urologist Dr Irwin Goldstein conducts study on reported link between decreased sexual desire in women and use of birth control pills; finds that sexual function does not immediately return for most women after discontinuing pills and suggests that elevated levels of sex hormone binding globulin, protein that renders free testosterone in blood inactive, is responsible; other theories about sexual desire and impact of birth control pills discussed; research is published in Journal of Sexual Medicine; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A controversial new study suggests that the birth control pill not only suppresses desire, but can also do so for months after a woman stops taking it.
